Sir, With reference to your letter No.98116/32 of 4th July 1932, transmitting copy of a report from the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, concerning a visit of Major Holmes to Q,atar to sound the Shaikh on the subject of an oil concession, I am commanded by My Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty to offer the following observations for the consideration of the Secretary of State for the Colonies. 2. The information contained in this report, when read in conjunction with the history of the Bahrein and Koweit Oil Concessions, would seem to indicate that the American interests behind the (British) Eastern and General Syndicate believe that the oil-bearing structure extends from the Eastern side of the Persian Gulf to the Western shores and runs under the Gulf itself (in the vicinity of the Farsi Islands); the Anglo-Persian Oil Company, however, have hitherto either been doubtful of the existence of oil in commercial quantities on the Western shores of the Gulf or have not wished to exploit it. 3. The fact that the Bahrein Petroleum Company has recently struck oil in some quantity would seem to confirm the opinion of the American geologists, while the recent ENCLOSURE IN WEEKLY LETTER No. £31 4 Alia 1932 The n n d 8 r c Secr,t*ry f O^ta^ 0M 8ECRETARYj p 0LITI0AL AR0 S.W.l. renewal/ ——. It will he recalled that, although the Bahrein concession granted to the Eastern and General Syndicate several years ago and transferred to American control *id not include adequate safeguards for British interests, it has been decided that the Koweit concession at present being negotiated with the Eastern and General Syndicate is to contain certain minimum safeguards if it is eventually awarded to that Syndicate. It now seems likely that the Eastern and General Syndicate may apply ^or a concession at $atar, and that, unless the Anglo-Persian Oil Company also apply for concessions in Koweit and/or Qatar, the Bahrein concession may gradually be merged into a much larger undertaking, the whole of which will be under the control of American interests, for the exploitation of the whole of the Horth-Western area of the Gulf. 5. My Lords consider it to be of the greatest importance that the safeguards agreed upon for Koweit should be the minimum for such an undertaking. They consider that no opportunity of applying the oweit safeguards to the Bahrein concession should be missed and suggest that a favourable opportunity will arise if the Eastern and General Syndicate apply for a concession in Qatar. The Qatar peninsula is so close to Bahrein (Bahrein to Doha is about 90 miles) that They suggest that it might be possible to contend that the Qatar concession is, in effect, an extension of the Bahrein concession and, therefore, to insist that as a pre condition to advising the Sheik to grant the Qatar concession the original Bahrein concession must be amended if Anr W: Vto include the safeguards. 7 6. My Lords are of opinion, however, that before the Qatar negotiations are further advanced, it is very advisable, in view of Article V of the Treaty of 1916, to ascertain the policy of the Anglo-Persian Oil Company with regard to Qatar. A British controlled oilfield in the Qatar district would be a strategic asset of great value owing to its comparative immunity from attack, and its proximity to the main sea lines of communication to the East. 7. Viewing the Persian Gulf oil position as a whole, My Lords regard it as unfortunate that American interests should already have secured such a strong position on the fringes of what was formerly an exclusively British- developed area and should now be seeking to extend their influence in that part of the area which is strategically the most important to British interests. They regard it as most important that no step should be neglected which might enable the Anglo-Persian Oil Company to bring this area within their sphere of control. 8. titleInfo.title: 'File 39/4 (10/4) Activities of Eastern and General Syndicate in Qatar'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers in the file are arranged chronologically. There are file notes at the end, on folio 15. The notes are arranged chronologically and refer to documents within the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 16; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-14; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the Political Agent at Bahrain, the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf and the Colonial Office regarding the interest of Frank Holmes, on behalf of Eastern and General Syndicate, in applying for an oil concession in Qatar.
